content: The description confuses tags and elements. Elements are nested, tags are not. The output is the number of elements, not the number of tags.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: It is good enough for a clash. Even though there are some non html formats which are not covered in the test. Those do not contradict the problem description. Maybe they contradict the title. But I think a title is just a title.

It looks very fun and I liked it.
My only suggestion would be providing some details in your goal section that take into consideration your test case Something Awry as some programmer may not know the order in which html tags should be opened and closed.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: As AndreMarasca wrote, this is a fun problem, slightly more difficult than the balanced brackets. It is suited for the CoC battles !

It is very similar to my clash: https://www.codingame.com/contribute/view/5706b2a82fd23416bb7eff1ff209bfa80d3a
But it's different enough.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

Maybe it would be interesting to consider the opposed case to "Not all closed". I mean check if there is closing tag before being open. So a test case such as (ohhh, evil typo on the first
tag !) Wich should output broken
This looks sweet for fast and shortest code clash ^^

From https://www.codingame.com/playgrounds/40701/contribute---help/contribution-guidelines :
"Binary or language-specific outputs should be avoided in CoC."

Your puzzle has binary outputs (only two possible values)
Without ANY understanding of the problem, print("True") or print("False") would score 50%. This is unfair, so isn't allowed.

True/False also favours a language (such as Python) which have True/False datatypes, but this is moot.
Thank you for the feedback, I'll rework it.
Thanks, I agree reverse might be a bit too hard.
Nice clash! I like how you combined it with palindromes. I didn't realise, as I haven't encountered it when clashing.
Also, input with an invalid tag such as "<" with no matching ">" should have the "Broken" output, surely?
Also also, there is a validator case to check for a closing tag at a time when there is no opening tag, but no corresponding visible test case.

Hi! Thank you for the feedback. I updated the description of the output from counting tags to elements. 

I still believe <, / and > characters should be allowed in the content between tags, as this is part of the challenge. Tags should consist of a name surrounded by angle brackets, the symbols on their own is just regular text. The number of possible tags is already narrowed to four, and there are no attributes. Open for more feedback.

Which validator does not match the test case sufficiently? I'd like to try to fix that.
Changed validator 3 to be in line with the corresponding test case.
I'm fine with reverse but I do believe there is plenty of people that don't have any HTML syntax knowladge so that might be hard for them to even understand what broken means :D
I changed it to output either the number of valid tags or "Broken". Currently, outputting "Broken" will still net 50%. I will add some more valid cases with longer inputs.
